data.context: [[Newton's first law of motion#Known Caveats|When observed from an intertial frame]], a [[rigid body|body]] acted on by no [[superposition of forces|net force]] exhibits:

- with constant (possibly zero) [[velocity]], 
                
---

Additionally, it is under the first law we have [[equilibrium]], the [[state|states]] where the net force is $\vec{0}$, and the body has constant [[velocity]] (no change in [[speed]] or [[direction]]) eg. for a given body, $$\sum{\vec{F_i}} = \vec{0} \implies \vec{v}=\vec{c}$$
- and zero [[acceleration]].

It is in this context there's [[inertia]], the propensity of motion to remain constant.
                
---

This law is only followed for observers in an [[inertia#Extending validity to other frames|inertial frame]] -- that is the observer and the body under consideration must have a constant [[relative velocity]]. #WaitWhat about constant relative speed?

data.id: core:Newton's third law of motion.md->core:rigid body.md1
data.context: If [[rigid body]] $A$ acts on $B$ (an "[[action]]") then body $B$ reacts to $A$ (a "reaction"), with the same magnitude and in the opposite direction. The two forces described act on different bodies.

data.id: core:Newton's third law of motion.md->core:action-reaction pair.md1
data.context:
The forces onto $A$ and $B$ are called an [[action-reaction pair]]
                
---

The two forces in an [[action-reaction pair]] **never** act on the same body.

data.id: core:Newton's third law of motion.md->core:contact force.md1

- [[work-energy theorem]]
In general for a [[force]] $\vec{F}$ and for a [[displacement]] $\vec{s}$ we have $$W = \vec{F}\cdot\vec{s} \ \ \text{(constant force, straight-line displacement)}$$

In general for a [[force]] $\vec{F}$ and for a [[displacement]] $\vec{s}$ we have $$W = \vec{F}\cdot\vec{s} \ \ \text{(constant force, straight-line displacement)}$$
                
---

- [[displacement]]

For a [[Kinematics along a straight line#with Variable Acceleration|varying force in straight-line motion]], $$W = \int_{x_1}^{x_2} F_xdx \ \ \ \ \ \ \text{(force varying with distance, straight-line displacement)}$$
For a [[spring]] we write $F_x = kx$ and so the [[spring potential energy]] $$W = \int_{0}^{X} kxdx = [\frac{k}{2}x^2] \ \bigg|_{0}^{X}=\frac{k}{2}X^2$$
For a [[spring]] we write $F_x = kx$ and so the [[spring potential energy]] $$W = \int_{0}^{X} kxdx = [\frac{k}{2}x^2] \ \bigg|_{0}^{X}=\frac{k}{2}X^2$$

And finally for [[Kinematics in space#acceleration in space|varying force in space]] we have that for a path $P$ from $P_1$ to $P_2$, the Work is given by the line integral: $$W=\int_{P_1}^{P_2}F\cos{\phi}dl=\int_{P_1}^{P_2}F_{||}dl=\int_P\vec{F}\cdot\vec{dl}$$
